issues.description: The problem statement explicitly requires a non-static method checkOrderReady() on SealSaloon (and instructs orderMeal() to call checkOrderReady()). However, the reference solution implements a method named processOrders() that provides the expected behavior and is called by orderMeal(), while there is no checkOrderReady() implementation. This name/signature mismatch between the specification and the solution can confuse students (they will implement checkOrderReady() as required by the text/UML) and makes the solution inconsistent with the documented API.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution match the problem specification by providing a method named checkOrderReady() with the expected (non-static) signature. For example, rename processOrders() to checkOrderReady(), or add a public checkOrderReady() that delegates to processOrders(). Ensure orderMeal() calls checkOrderReady() as described in the problem statement so the API and reference implementation align with the documentation.

issues.description: The problem statement and class diagram require a method named checkOrderReady() in SealSaloon (used by orderMeal()). The provided solution implementation uses a method named processOrders() (and orderMeal() calls processOrders()). This is a naming mismatch for the same conceptual behavior (serving orders when ingredients are available), which can confuse students trying to map the specification to the implementation and tests that refer to checkOrderReady().
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name across artifacts. Either rename the solution method processOrders() to checkOrderReady() (and keep orderMeal() calling checkOrderReady()), or update the problem statement/tests to reference processOrders(). Prefer renaming the implementation to checkOrderReady() to match the specification and avoid student confusion.
